thread.title: Man Booker Prize 2015 shortlist: Hanya Yanagihara's A Little Life firms as favourite
thread.title_full: Man Booker Prize 2015 shortlist: Hanya Yanagihara's A Little Life firms as favourite

author: Linda Morris
title: Man Booker Prize 2015 shortlist: Hanya Yanagihara's A Little Life firms as favourite
text:
Hana Yanagihara is the bookies' favourite to win the Man Booker Prize for her novel A Little Lie. 
Among a field of largely unknowns, the bookies' favourite to win this year's Man Booker Prize – to be announced in London on Tuesday night (Wednesday morning AEDT) – is firming as Hanya Yanagihara's​  A Little Life .
Yanagihara's story follows four young men from university to adulthood with a particular focus on the emotional pain of one, lawyer and mathematician Jude St Francis.
The bookies aren't always right, as last year's winner, Australia's Richard Flanagan, can gladly attest.
A Little Life by Hanya Yanagihara. 
The other shortlisted titles include  The Year of the Runaways the second novel of Sunjeev Sahota, which traces a year in the lives of three Indian migrants finding their way in Sheffield, England.
Advertisement A Brief History of Seven Killings by Marlon James spins out from the attempted assassination of Bob Marley in 1976 into a multi-layered, colourful account of Jamaican politics.
A Spool of Blue Thread by Anne Tyler is a multi-generational story of the Whitshanks, told as a family gathers to ponder how to care for their ageing parents.
The Fishermen is the first novel of Nigerian-born Chigozie Obioma​. Narrated by the youngest of four brothers, it shows the destructive power of a prophecy that foretells the death of one brother by the hand of another.
Satin Island by American Tom McCarthy is an unconventional novel that revolves around a corporate anthropologist named U who has been given the task by his superiors of composing a "great report" to sum up his age.  
Go to smh.com.au/entertainment for the announcement of the Booker Prize 2015 winner
